INFO 2950: 
Intro to 
Data 
Science
Lecture 26
2023-11-29
1

Agenda

1.
Python Review


2.
Midterm Review 

(Part 1)




2

When to use what languages?

●
Python

○
Data manipulation

○
ML models



3

When to use what languages?

●
Python

○
Data manipulation

○
ML models


●
SQL

○
Merging data, group by’s

4

In Python, (with documentation/Googling) you 
should now be able to do the following with 
dataframes:

5

In Python, (with documentation/Googling) you 
should now be able to do the following with 
dataframes:

6

●
select rows, columns

●
do arithmetic transforms of a column

●
generate new rows / columns

●
merges, sorting, data transformations

●
aggregate statistics / group by

●
run linear and logistic regressions

●
run hypothesis tests / generate distributions

●
run advanced models: NB, SVD, neural nets...

Python refresher / R intro

7

●
We’ll review basic 
syntax from the first 
few lectures

●
...and introduce how 
to do the same things 
in R!


https://www.business-science.io/business/2
021/02/18/R-is-for-research.html

Python refresher / R intro

8

You won’t need to know R 
for the final exam, but we 
want to show you that 
much of what you learned 
is 
transferable knowledge!

https://www.business-science.io/business/2
021/02/18/R-is-for-research.html

R

9

●
Designed by statisticians, not CS


●
Harder to use as 
general-purpose programming 
language, but easier for 
stats-oriented  work


●
Lagging Python for recent NNs


●
Base R is ok, "tidyverse" 
packages are 


https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm/r-plugin-support.html
 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R_%28programming_l
anguage%29

Python      : Loading libraries

import numpy as 
__

import pandas as 
__

import seaborn


10

琀
琀

Python vs R: Loading libraries

import numpy as np

import pandas as pd

import seaborn


library(tidyverse)


──
 Attaching packages 
─
 tidyverse 1.3.1 
──

✔
 ggplot2 3.3.6     
✔
 purrr   0.3.4

✔
 tibble  3.1.7     
✔
 dplyr   1.0.9

✔
 tidyr   1.2.0     
✔
 stringr 1.4.0

✔
 readr   2.1.2     
✔
 forcats 0.5.1

──
 Conflicts 
───
 tidyverse_conflicts() 
──

✖
 dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()

✖
 dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()


11

Python      : Reading a file

countries = 
pd.
_______
("countries.tsv", 
delimiter="
__
")


12

琀
琀

Python vs R: Reading a file

countries = 
pd.read_csv("countries.tsv", 
delimiter="\t")


countries <- read_tsv("countries.tsv")

Rows: 230 Columns: 63 
                                                 

──
 Column specification
──

Delimiter: "\t"

chr (34): Country, Continent, Region, Location, Highest 
Point, Langua...

dbl (28): Area, Borders, Length, Coastline, Height, 
Temperature, Popu...


ℹ
 Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification 
for this data.

ℹ
 Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = 
FALSE` to quiet this message.



13

Python vs R: Reading a file

countries = 
pd.read_csv("countries.tsv", 
delimiter="\t")


countries <- read_tsv("countries.tsv")



14

RStudio keeps track 
of defined variables 
and their sizes

Python      : Show the first 3 rows

countries.
____
(3)


15

琀
琀

Python vs R: Show the first rows

countries.head(3)


head(countries, 3)


or 


countries %>% head(3)



16

Python vs R: Show the first rows

countries.head(3)


head(countries, 3)


or 


countries %>% head(3)



17

"pipe" operator


value on the left becomes 
input to the right

Python      : Show two columns

countries
__
"Country", 
"Population"
__


18

琀
琀

Python vs R: Show two columns

countries[["Country", 
"Population"]]


countries %>% select(Country, 
Population)

19

Python vs R: Show two columns

countries[["Country", 
"Population"]]


countries %>% select(Country, 
Population)

20

R can figure out that 
"Population" is a column 
name, so it doesn't need 
quotes

Python     : Select rows by condition

countries.
____
 
countries["Population"] > 
100000000 
_


21

琀
琀

Python vs R: Select rows by condition

countries.loc[ 
countries["Population"] > 
100000000 ]


countries %>% 
filter(Population > 
100000000)

22

Research Question: 

do more urbanized countries 
have larger populations? 

23

Python     : Sort rows by a column

countries.
___________
 
(by="Urban")[["Country", 
"Urban"]]


24

琀
琀

Python vs R: Sort rows by a column

countries.sort_values 
(by="Urban")[["Country", 
"Urban"]]


countries %>% arrange(Urban) 
%>% select(Country, Urban)

25

Pipes allow us to 
combine multiple 
operations

Python vs R: Sort rows by a column

countries.sort_values 
(by="Urban")[["Country", 
"Urban"]]


26

seaborn.
________
(data=countries, 
x="
________
", y="
________
")

Python vs R: plot data as points

seaborn.scatterplot(data=countries, 
x="Population", y="Urban")


ggplot(data=countries, 
aes(Population, Urban)) + 
geom_point()

countries[
_________
] = 
np.
___
(

[
______
])

琀

Python vs R: Add a "LogPopulation" column

countries["LogPopulation"] = 
np.log(countries["Populat
ion"])




countries <- countries %>% 
mutate(LogPopulation = 
log(Population))

30

Python vs R: Add a "LogPopulation" column

countries["LogPopulation"] = 
np.log(countries["Populat
ion"])




countries <- countries %>% 
mutate(LogPopulation = 
log(Population))

RStudio helps with 
API hints (also Google 
Colab and VSCode for 
Python)

Python: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model = LinearRegression()

.
___
(countries[["Urban"]], countries["LogPopulation"])


urban_pop_model.
_______
, urban_pop_model.
________


(array([-0.0051409]), 16.475302332927527)




32

琀
琀

Python: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model = LinearRegression()

.fit(countries[["Urban"]], countries["LogPopulation"])


urban_pop_model.coef_, urban_pop_model.intercept_


(array([-0.0051409]), 16.475302332927527)




33

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






34

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






35

R uses "~" to build a 
formula for linear models

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






36

Is our coefficient > 
or < 0?

琀
琀

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






37

Urban coefficient 
slightly < 0

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






38

Is our coefficient 
“statistically 
significant”?

琀
琀

R: Predict population from Urban%

urban_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban, data=countries)

summary(urban_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.8100 -0.9732  0.1155  1.2519  4.8958 


Coefficients:

            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept) 16.475302   0.479951  34.327   <2e-16 ***

Urban       -0.005141   0.007324  -0.702    0.484 
   

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.97 on 142 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.003458,

Adjusted R-squared:  -0.00356 

F-statistic: 0.4927 on 1 and 142 DF,  p-value: 0.4839






39

Nope! 

The intercept is 
definitely
 not zero, 
but Urban% looks 
random

R: Predict population from Urban% + Area

ur_ar_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban + Area, data=countries)

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.4715 -0.9001  0.2607  1.1208  3.6736 


Coefficients:

              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept)  1.644e+01  4.378e-01  37.544  < 2e-16 ***

Urban       -9.844e-03  6.736e-03  -1.462    0.146 
   

Area         3.765e-07  6.911e-08   5.448 2.21e-07 ***

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.797 on 141 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.1768,

Adjusted R-squared:  0.1651 

F-statistic: 15.14 on 2 and 141 DF,  p-value: 1.108e-06







40

Include multiple 
predictors with +

R: Predict population from Urban% + Area

ur_ar_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban + Area, data=countries)

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.4715 -0.9001  0.2607  1.1208  3.6736 


Coefficients:

              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept)  1.644e+01  4.378e-01  37.544  < 2e-16 ***

Urban       -9.844e-03  6.736e-03  -1.462    0.146 
   

Area         3.765e-07  6.911e-08   5.448 2.21e-07 ***

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.797 on 141 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.1768,

Adjusted R-squared:  0.1651 

F-statistic: 15.14 on 2 and 141 DF,  p-value: 1.108e-06







41

1.
Is Urban coefficient 
statistically significant 
at the 0.001 level?

2.
Is Area coefficient 
statistically significant 
at the 0.001 level?

琀
琀

R: Predict population from Urban% + Area

ur_ar_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban + Area, data=countries)

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.4715 -0.9001  0.2607  1.1208  3.6736 


Coefficients:

              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept)  1.644e+01  4.378e-01  37.544  < 2e-16 ***

---

Multiple R-squared:  0.1768,

Adjusted R-squared:  0.1651 

F-statistic: 15.14 on 2 and 141 DF,  p-value: 1.108e-06







42

1. No 2. Yes


Urban% is still not 
significant, but 
lower p value.

Land area is highly 
significant!

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Which coefficient has 
larger magnitude, Urban 
or Area?

琀
琀

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max

44

Magnitude means absolute 
value; 
Urban
’s is bigger: 

0.009844 > 0.0000003765

ur_ar_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban + Area, data=countries)

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.4715 -0.9001  0.2607  1.1208  3.6736 


Coefficients:

              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)

45

1 unit (percentage point) increase in 
Urban% corresponds to a 
______
 
[increase/decrease]
 in log population.


1 unit (square miles) increase in Area 
corresponds to a 
______
 
[increase/decrease]
  in log population.

琀
琀

R: Predict population from Urban% + Area

ur_ar_pop_model <- lm(LogPopulation ~ Urban + Area, data=countries)

summary(ur_ar_pop_model)

Residuals:

    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 

-6.4715 -0.9001  0.2607  1.1208  3.6736 


Coefficients:

              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) 
   

(Intercept)  1.644e+01  4.378e-01  37.544  < 2e-16 ***

Urban       -9.844e-03  6.736e-03  -1.462    0.146 
   

Area         3.765e-07  6.911e-08   5.448 2.21e-07 ***

---

Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1


Residual standard error: 1.797 on 141 degrees of freedom

Multiple R-squared:  0.1768,

Adjusted R-squared:  0.1651 

F-statistic: 15.14 on 2 and 141 DF,  p-value: 1.108e-06







46

1 unit (percentage point) increase 
in Urban% corresponds to a .0098 
decrease in log population.


1 unit (square miles) increase in 
Area corresponds to a 
0.0000003765 increase in log 
population. Small but significant!

Python: Predict population from Urban%

outputs,  predictors = patsy.dmatrices("LogPopulation ~ Urban", 
data=countries, return_type="dataframe")

sm_urban_pop_model = sm.OLS(outputs, predictors).fit()

sm_urban_pop_model.summary()





47

Using 
statsmodels
 
package

outputs,  predictors = patsy.dmatrices("LogPopulation ~ Urban", 
data=countries, return_type="dataframe")

sm_urban_pop_model = sm.OLS(outputs, predictors).fit()

sm_urban_pop_model.summary()





Python: Predict population from Urban%

48

dmatrices uses the same 
formula syntax as R

outputs,  predictors = patsy.dmatrices("LogPopulation ~ Urban", 
data=countries, return_type="dataframe")

sm_urban_pop_model = sm.OLS(outputs, predictors).fit()

sm_urban_pop_model.summary()





Python: Predict population from Urban%

49

statsmodels does not 
include intercept by 
default, dmatrices 
function adds an 
intercept

Python: Predict population from Urban%

outputs,  predictors = patsy.dmatrices("LogPopulation ~ Urban", 
data=countries, return_type="dataframe")

sm_urban_pop_model = sm.OLS(outputs, predictors).fit()

sm_urban_pop_model.summary()

Python     : inner join of df1 and df2 (on 
column ‘id’)


df1.merge(df2, how=’inner’, 
on=‘id’)

(Using Pandas merge!)

SQL     : inner join of df1 and df2 (on column 
‘id’)


df1.merge(df2, how=’inner’, 
on=‘id’)


SELECT * 

FROM df1 

_____ ____
 
___
 

___
 df1.id 
___
 df2.id 

55

(Using Pandas merge!)

(Using SQL merge!)

琀
琀

SQL     : inner join of df1 and df2 (on column 
‘id’)


df1.merge(df2, how=’inner’, 
on=‘id’)


SELECT * 

FROM df1 

INNER JOIN df2 

ON df1.id = df2.id 

56

Python & SQL & R: inner join of df1 and df2 
(on column ‘id’)


df1.merge(df2, how=‘inner’, 
on=‘id’)

—--------------------------

SELECT * 

FROM df1 

INNER JOIN df2 

ON df1.id = df2.id 

57

Using Base R:

merge(df1, df2, by=‘id’)


Using dplyr package:

df1 %>% inner_join(df2,by=‘id’)

Python & SQL & R: get average ‘price’ 
grouped by ‘product’ from dataframe ‘df’

df.groupby(‘product’)[‘price’].
mean()



SELECT AVG(price)

FROM df

GROUP BY product

62

(Using Pandas!)

(Using SQL!)

df %>% group_by(product) 

   %>% summarise(mean(price))

(Using R tidyverse)

Numpy stats in 1-D

>>> a = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])

>>> 
__
.
_____





(2,2)

>>> np.mean(a, axis=0)



?

>>> np.median(a, axis=1)


?

https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.mean.html
 

琀
琀
 

63

Numpy stats in 1-D

>>> a = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])

>>> np.shape





(2,2)

>>> np.mean(a, axis=0)



array([2., 3.])

>>> np.median(a, axis=1)


array([1.5, 3.5])

https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.mean.html
 

64

Numpy stats in 1-D

>>> a = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])

>>> __._____





(2,2)

>>> np.mean(a, axis=0)



array([2., 3.])

>>> np.median(a, axis=1)


array([1.5, 3.5])

https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.mean.html
 

Remember: median minimizes sum of “absolute distances” 
but the Python default is the midpoint!
